subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] Re: A little story in Romanized QS
msgSnippet: It seems to be being ignored that the 8 basic abbreviations are intended to be used with Junior QS - see QM p12. Another point, people are referring to British
messageBody:
It seems to be being ignored that the 8 basic abbreviations are intended to be used with Junior QS - see QM p12.

Another point, people are referring to British English.  a) British is a nationality not a country and b) there is no such thing as British English - there is southern English, West country, Yorkshire, BBC English, Scouse, Brummy, Geordie, Scottish (with varieties), Irish (with varieties), Welsh (with varieties) - all of whom would have their peculiar ways of pronouncing vowel sounds.

In other words, there are as many varieties of English spoken in the British Isles as there are in the US and other English speaking nations.

Climbing down from my soapbox now.....

Moira

On 06/11/2007, Anthony Grahn <othermale@...> wrote:

Absolutely Excellent! We now have something in New Zealand-ian to
genuinely compare. The question now merely is are they equally
(un)readable. Thanks!

FYI: They would be slightly more similar using the senior
abbreviations and I personally do not believe it is a sin to use
Senior abbreviations when writing in Junior mode.



--- In Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com, John Cowan <cowan@...> wrote:
>
> Here's a little story in lexical-set QS with my personal set of mergers
> (and accepting Read's special conventions, including It in HAPPY words):
>
> They S-Utter-They-Utter-R-L-It W-It-N-D N They S-Utter-N W-Utter-R
> D-It-S-P-Y-Ooze-T-Ing W-I-Ch W-Utter-Z They S-T-R-Awe-Ing-G-Utter-R,
> W-Et-N Utter T-R-At-V-Utter-L-Utter-R K-Eight-M Utter-L-Aw-Ing R-At-P-T
> It-N Utter W-Awe-R-M K-L-Owe-K. They-Eight Utter-G-R-Eat-D They-At-T
> They W-Utter-N H-Ooze F-Utter-R-S-T S-Utter-K-S-Eat-D-Utter-D It-N
> M-Eight-K-Ing They T-R-At-V-Utter-L-Utter-R T-Eight-K H-It-Z K-L-Owe-K V
> Sh-Foot-D B K-Utter-N-S-It-D-Utter-R-D S-T-R-Awe-Ing-G-Utter-R They-At-N
> They Utter-They-Utter-R. They-Et-N They S-Utter-They-Utter-R-L-It
> B-L-Ooze At-Z H-Ah-R-D At-Z H-Eat K-Foot-D, B-Utter-T They M-Awe-R H-Eat
> B-L-Ooze, They M-Awe-R K-L-Owe-S-L-It They T-R-At-V-Utter-L-Utter-R
> R-At-P-T H-It-Z K-L-Owe-K Utter-R-Out-N-D H-It-M, N At-T L-At-S-T They
> S-Utter-They-Utter-R-L-It G-Aight-V Utter-P They Utter-T-Et-M-P-T.
> They-Et-N They S-Utter-N Sh-Owe-N Out-T W-Awe-R-M-L-It, N
> It-M-Eat-D-Eat-Utter-L-It They T-R-At-V-Utter-L-Utter-R T-Foot-K Awe-F
> H-It-Z K-L-Owe-K. N S-Owe They S-Utter-They-Utter-R-L-It W-Utter-Z
> Utter-B-L-I-J-D T-Ooze K-Utter-N-F-Et-S They-At-T They S-Utter-N
W-Utter-Z
> They S-T-R-Awe-Ing-G-Utter-R V They T-Ooze.
> Note that LOT = PALM and THOUGHT = CLOTH, as I have said before.
> If you want the TO form, google for "The North Wind and the Sun" and
> just replace "North" with "Southerly".
>
> Now here's the same story, but in phonetic QS as a New
> Zealander might write it, based on an IPA transcription of
> a New Zealander reading the story aloud, available online at
>
http://journals.cambridge.org/production/action/cjoGetFulltext?fulltextid=995732
>
> They S-Ah-They-Utter-R-L-It W-Utter-N-D N They S-Ah-N W-Utter-R
> D-Utter-S-P-Y-Ooze-T-Ing W-Utter-Ch W-utter-Z They
S-T-R-Ox-Ing-G-Utter-R,
> W-Eight-N Utter T-R-Et-V-L-Ah K-At-Eight-M Utter-L-Ox-Ing R-Et-P-T
Utter-N
> Utter W-Owe-M K-L-Out-K. They-At-Eight Utter-G-R-Eat-D They-Utter-T
> They W-Ah-N H-Ooze F-Utter-R-S-T S-Ah-K-S-Utter-D-Utter-D Utter-N
> M-At-Eight-K-Ing They T-R-Et-V-L-Ah T-At-Eight-K Ox-F H-Utter-Z
K-L-Out-K
> Ox-F Sh-Foot-D B K-Utter-N-S-Utter-S-Utter-D S-T-R-Ox-Ing-G-Utter-R
> They-Utter-N They Ah-They-Ah. They-Ate-N They S-Ah-They-Utter-R-L-It
> B-L-Ooze Et-Z H-Ah-R-D Et-Z H-Eat K-Foot-D, B-Utter-T They M-Owe-R H-Eat
> B-L-Ooze, They M-Owe-R They T-R-Et-V-L-Ah R-Et-P-T H-Utter-Z K-L-Out-K
> Utter-R-At-Owe-N-D H-Utter-M, N Et-T L-Ah-S-T They
S-Ah-They-Utter-R-L-It
> G-At-Eat-V Ah-P They Utter-T-Eight-M-P-T. They-Eight-N They S-Ah-N
> Sh-An-N At-Owe-T W-Owe-M-L-It, N Utter-M-Eat-D-Eat-Utter-T-L-It
> They T-R-Et-V-L-Ah T-Foot-K Ah-F H-Utter-Z K-L-Out-K. N S-Out
> They S-Ah-They-Utter-R-L-It W-Utter-Z Utter-B-L-Ah-Eight-J-D
> T-Ooze K-Utter-N-F-Eight-S They-Utter-T They S-Ah-N W-Utter-Z They
> S-T-R-Ox-Ing-G-Utter-R V They T-Ooze.
>
> I have used At-Eight, Ah-Eight, and At-Owe for the distinctive NZ
> diphthongs that are used for the FACE, PRICE, and MOUTH lexical sets
> respectively. There is also Owe-Eight, which doesn't appear in the
story,
> for the CHOICE set. These are the nearest equivalents in phonetic QS
> provided they are pronounced as a single sound: the first starts at At
> and winds up at Eight, and so on.
>
> As you all can see, these renderings share the same consonants, but
> are extremely different in the vowels. I think it would be very hard
> for someone from the U.S. or the U.K. to read this version fluently.
> But if a New Zealander used the lexical sets sensibly, then things like
> the KIT = COMMA merger visible above would go away, even though they
sound
> the same, because the rule would be "Write It in stressed syllables,
> write Utter in unstressed ones." The strange diphthongs also vanish
> in favor of the Eight, I, Owe, and Oy letters, and except for BATH =
> PALM instead of BATH = TRAP, and the absence of LOT = CLOTH, the New
> Zealand version would look the same as mine!
>
> (NZ has two other splits, GOAT/GOLD stressed, and COMMA/TREACLE
> unstressed, that involve yet another vowel QS has no letter for, so they
> cannot be represented in the phonetic version. For better or worse,
> it does not appear in the story anyhow.)
>
> I hope this helps people see my point. Any errors are of course my own,
> and I'd appreciate corrections.
>
> --
> Long-short-short, long-short-short / Dactyls in dimeter, John Cowan
> Verse form with choriambs / (Masculine rhyme): cowan@...
> One sentence (two stanzas) / Hexasyllabically
> Challenges poets who / Don't have the time. --robison who's at
texas dot net
>




--
Moira O'Brien
